claim.hypothesis: Women are more concerned about COVID-19 than men.
claim.hypothesis_location: Gender differences in concern are reported in the Results section under 'Fear', page 5, where women show higher agreement that they are worried about COVID-19.
claim.statement: The study finds that women report significantly higher concern about COVID-19 than men, with 68.2% of women agreeing that they are worried about COVID-19 compared to 55.7% of men (p < .01).

data.source: Online access panel survey of adults in Germany conducted by an ISO-certified panel provider.
data.notes: Respondents were quota-sampled to be online-representative by gender, age, and federal state. All survey questions were mandatory. Respondents who completed the survey in under seven minutes were removed.

method.description: The study measured concern about COVID-19 using Likert-scale items and compared responses between women and men to assess gender differences in expressed concern.
steps: Administer a mandatory-question online survey to adult respondents in Germany.
Measure concern using the item: 'The COVID-19 worries me' on a 5-point Likert scale.
Calculate the percentage of respondents agreeing ('strongly agree' or 'agree') by gender.
Compare percentages between women and men and report statistical significance.
method.models: not stated (results reported as descriptive percentages with significance testing).
method.outcome_variable: Agreement with the statement 'The COVID-19 worries me' (5-point Likert scale, summarized as percentage agreeing).
method.control_variables: not stated (no regression or adjusted model is reported).

results.summary: Women express significantly more concern about COVID-19 than men, as measured by agreement with the statement 'The COVID-19 worries me.'

numerical_results.outcome_name: Percentage agreeing they are worried about COVID-19

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19: Risk perception and coping strategies. Results from a survey in Germany.
